author: arnetheduck
content: for the testnet, instead of draining the goerli eth2 deposit with an explicit call, an easy alternative we've been thinking of is simply returning the ETH to the tx origin in the registration call (so that the goeth is not lost when testnet is restarted).. anyone doing that?\

author: paulhauner
content: you need to get them to pull the eth back out

author: paulhauner
content: those things where you iterate through a list of people and send them money usually end up running out of gas

author: paulhauner
content: or do you mean they get a refund immediately after they deposit?

author: paulhauner
content: or you can do a multi-call, queue based refund thing to avoid the gas problem

author: jgm
content: <@449019668296892420> it also depends on the method being used to give them the Goerli Ether.  If it's through your own web UI as part of setting up the validator (a la prysm) then sending them back the funds may be less useful than being able to drain them and return them to your own contract than leave them with whomever is running the validator

author: arnetheduck
content:
> or do you mean they get a refund immediately after they deposit?

this - the deposit call itself could be modified to return.. perhaps..

author: paulhauner
content: it would allow people to spam validators a little more

author: protolambda
content: At that point, maybe just make it cheaper/free? Or do you mean to directly forward the testnet eth to the contract creator instead?

author: jgm
content: <@203220829473996800> if a return of Ether is wanted then either a drain or a transfer back to sender would be preferable, in my mind, as the former does not touch `deposit()` and the latter is a one-line addition at the end of it.  Changes in the "value" of Ether sent to the deposit contract requires changes to existing code so is more likely to create a scenario where conditions in the final deployed contract do not match those in the contracts deployed for testing

author: arnetheduck
content: what we've done for now is add a function to get your goeth back, but it's kind of onerous to have to call that at  the end of a testnet run.. hence..
